Comments_List: An overview of current issues in migration studies and an understanding of different methodological approaches to migration research.
Knowledge about migration studies in a comparative and interdisciplinary view; Fruitful discussions about the facts and analysis about the global migration, and its importance in empirical studies.

In this class I gained the skill of comprehensively reading through political science methodology pertaining to immigration flows and patterns. I also gained the skill of speaking in a small seminar about complex issues.

Emily was a great discussion leader, and created a very comprehensive syllabus for us to work from. As an early PhD student putting together migration-related research, I found this course extremely helpful in situating my work within a broader context. In future years if there are more PhD students who take the course, it would be great to incorporate time to workshop students' research projects/proposals and spend more time discussing methods in particular. But given the makeup of students in our class, the format we had worked well.

I think the regional presentations can be better structured, for instance, to anchor them with the topic to be discussed in the class. Moreover, since it is graduate course, I think in-depth discussions about the research design could be also helpful. But this course was already well designed and structured!

A strength of this course was that it provided a gamut of readings (books, articles, literature reviews) from economic, political, and sociological perspectives. A weakness of this course was that it didnt seem to tie the topics we covered together as we went. It felt like each week was a different segment.
This is a great survey course in migration research, which covers political science, economic, sociological, and historic texts. It is a well-run and focused class. I would definitely recommend it.

Definitely. The lecturer is very experienced in a variety of disciplines, and can organise them well with regard to a substantive focus. Students who are interested in migration and its implication for public policies can learn much in this course. The weekly short reading responses also facilitates the in-depth discussion in the seminar.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It will broaden your understanding of immigration and will help you formulate a more bipartisan perspective on how immigration policy formulation requires an intense understanding of sovereignty, boundary control, and cultural identity.
Absolutely - professor was incredibly knowledgeable and the subject matter was exceptional in both breadth and depth.
